content.title: Aortobifemoral Bypass (ABF)
content.definition: Open surgical bypass using a prosthetic Y-graft from the infrarenal aorta to both common femoral arteries, bypassing aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD). Gold standard surgical treatment for TASC D aortoiliac lesions with excellent long-term patency (85-90% at 5 years).

key_concepts.description: Severe aortoiliac occlusive disease (TASC C-D lesions); lifestyle-limiting claudication failing medical therapy; critical limb-threatening ischemia from AIOD; combined with lower extremity procedures
Knitted or woven Dacron (polyester); ePTFE (PTFE) less common for aortic position; Y-configuration (bifurcated graft) with limbs to each femoral
Transperitoneal (midline laparotomy) or retroperitoneal (left flank incision) for aortic exposure; bilateral groin incisions for femoral anastomoses
End-to-end (aorta divided) or end-to-side to infrarenal aorta; end-to-end preferred if no significant hypogastric disease; infrarenal clamp typical
End-to-side to common femoral artery; concomitant femoral endarterectomy often needed; may extend to profunda femoris if CFA severely diseased
Graft limbs tunneled retroperitoneally, anterior to ureters, under inguinal ligament to groins; avoid kinking or tension
Primary patency 85-90% at 5 years, 75-80% at 10 years; superior to endovascular treatment for TASC D lesions; gold standard comparison
Early: bleeding, myocardial infarction, renal injury, colonic ischemia (2-3%), spinal cord ischemia (rare), limb loss. Late: graft infection, anastomotic aneurysm, aortoenteric fistula
Retrograde ejaculation/impotence from hypogastric nerve injury during aortic dissection; more common with end-to-end proximal anastomosis; careful dissection technique important
Occurs in 2-3%; from IMA ligation, hypogastric hypoperfusion, hypotension; left colon most vulnerable; sigmoidoscopy if suspected; high mortality if untreated

learning_objectives: Know the surgical approach and anastomotic options
Recognize complications especially colonic ischemia and sexual dysfunction
Appreciate excellent long-term patency (85-90% at 5 years)
clinical_pearls: Gold standard for TASC C/D aortoiliac disease
85-90% patency at 5 years - benchmark for other treatments
End-to-end proximal anastomosis more technically challenging but better flow
Always assess pelvic circulation to minimize sexual dysfunction
2-3% colonic ischemia - monitor and do sigmoidoscopy if suspicious
Retroperitoneal approach avoids bowel handling, may reduce AEF risk
common_mistakes: Not doing femoral endarterectomy when CFA diseased
Tunneling graft through peritoneum instead of retroperitoneal
